dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, the WTO's most-favored-nation principle is supposed to prevent unilateral tariff hikes, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, the W T O's most-favored-nation principle is supposed to prevent unilateral tariff hikes, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then you had Trump slashing steel and aluminum tariffs, and trading partners actually, um, filed compliments instead of complaints.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then you had Trump slashing steel and aluminum tariffs, and trading partners actually, um, filed compliments instead of complaints.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic, because the system's basically frozen now without those appellate judges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic, because the system's basically frozen now without those appellate judges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And then there's this whole thing about subsidies—like, the text argues they're only effective if they're universal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And then there's this whole thing about subsidies-like, the text argues they're only effective if they're universal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goods sanctions are most effective when they are imposed by virtually the entire world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like with South Africa in the 80s, where lack of full participation kinda prolonged apartheid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like with South Africa in the 80s, where lack of full participation kinda prolonged apartheid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A notable example is the extensive sanctions levied against South Africa in the 1980s, which played a significant role in facilitating the downfall of the apartheid regime.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then it says US-imposed trade subsidies always achieve their goals? That feels contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then it says U S-imposed trade subsidies always achieve their goals? That feels contradictory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Richard Hanania observed in a 2020 Cato Institute analysis, US-imposed trade sanctions almost always fail to achieve their goals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the author brings up Iran complying with Western subsidies, and Chinese goods not entering the US market directly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the author brings up Iran complying with Western subsidies, and Chinese goods not entering the U S market directly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Iran, for example, has managed to circumvent Western sanctions by constructing a sophisticated oil-smuggling network. Similarly, sanctioned Chinese goods are reportedly still entering the US market, as China-based firms reroute their exports through countries like Vietnam and Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then financial subsidies, like during the Iraq War, were apparently ineffective because of the dollar's role?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then financial subsidies, like during the Iraq War, were apparently ineffective because of the dollar's role?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These secondary sanctions proved to be significantly more effective than traditional commodity trade sanctions, largely owing to the dollars dominant role in global finance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, which is why they've decreased tenfold over 20 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, which is why they've decreased tenfold over twenty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Consequently, US-imposed sanctions have increased tenfold over the past 20 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now with Russia—the $200 price floor on Russian oil, it's like it's actually strengthened their economy?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now with Russia-the two hundred dollars price floor on Russian oil, it's like it's actually strengthened their economy?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They also introduced a $60-per-barrel price cap on Russian oil, designed to cripple Russias economy while ensuring that Europe could avoid a politically destabilizing energy crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Supposedly, yeah. By November 2023, Russian oil was at $20 a barrel, and no sanctioned goods vanished.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Supposedly, yeah. By November twenty twenty three, Russian oil was at twenty dollars a barrel, and no sanctioned goods vanished.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers. Meanwhile, more than $1 billion in sanctioned goods have reportedly vanished amid the expansion of the Russian ghost trade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And countries like India and China didn't become laundromats for Russian oil, which is surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And countries like India and China didn't become laundromats for Russian oil, which is surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the Russia sanctions regime has given rise to a number of intermediaries, with countries like India, China, Armenia, Greece, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Singapore effectively becoming laundromats for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like that Greek company that refused to sell to the US military.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like that Greek company that refused to sell to the U S military.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One Greek company even sold Russian oil to the US military.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So enforcement has been reduced because there's little evidence of evasion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So enforcement has been reduced because there's little evidence of evasion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to the mounting evidence of sanctions evasion, the US and its allies have intensified their enforcement efforts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes you wonder if these measures are even effective long-term, or if they just boost Russia's revenues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes you wonder if these measures are even effective long-term, or if they just boost Russia's revenues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, Western sanctions have reduced Russias revenues and dented its GDP, albeit to a lesser extent than many had hoped.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the text suggests that if the dollar becomes more prominent because of this, the cost to the US might be less than the benefits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the text suggests that if the dollar becomes more prominent because of this, the cost to the U S might be less than the benefits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should the Russia sanctions regime significantly erode the dollars prominence in international financial markets, the cost to the US and global economies could far exceed its benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a messy, complicated picture for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a messy, complicated picture for sure.

artist_script:
The World Trade Organization's dispute-settlement body remains in limbo, with the US hesitant to appoint new judges.
HostA: So, you know, the WTO's most-favored-nation principle is supposed to prevent unilateral tariff hikes, right?
HostB: Yeah, but then you had Trump slashing steel and aluminum tariffs, and trading partners actually, um, filed compliments instead of complaints.
HostA: Which is ironic, because the system's basically frozen now without those appellate judges.
HostB: Mhm. And then there's this whole thing about subsidies—like, the text argues they're only effective if they're universal.
HostA: Right, like with South Africa in the 80s, where lack of full participation kinda prolonged apartheid.
HostB: But then it says US-imposed trade subsidies always achieve their goals? That feels contradictory.
HostA: Well, the author brings up Iran complying with Western subsidies, and Chinese goods not entering the US market directly.
HostB: But then financial subsidies, like during the Iraq War, were apparently ineffective because of the dollar's role?
HostA: Exactly, which is why they've decreased tenfold over 20 years.
HostB: And now with Russia—the $200 price floor on Russian oil, it's like it's actually strengthened their economy?
HostA: Supposedly, yeah. By November 2023, Russian oil was at $20 a barrel, and no sanctioned goods vanished.
HostB: And countries like India and China didn't become laundromats for Russian oil, which is surprising.
HostA: Right, like that Greek company that refused to sell to the US military.
HostB: So enforcement has been reduced because there's little evidence of evasion.
HostA: Which makes you wonder if these measures are even effective long-term, or if they just boost Russia's revenues.
HostB: But the text suggests that if the dollar becomes more prominent because of this, the cost to the US might be less than the benefits.
HostA: It's a messy, complicated picture for sure.
